comment_text.mn51:1.2: Campā is modern Champapur near Bhagalpur in Bihar state, not far from West Bengal. It is near the eastern-most reach of the Buddha’s journeys. Campā was the capital of Aṅga, one of the sixteen “great nations” (mahājanapadā). It was a flourishing trade center, and became a sacred city for the Jains. | Gaggarā, an onomatopoeic reduplication (“gargle”), is the name of a number of rivers and whirlpools in Sanskrit (cp. the modern Ghaggar River in north-west India).
comment_text.mn51:2.4: Kandaraka’s status as a (non-Buddhist) wanderer does not preclude his faith in the Buddha.
comment_text.mn51:3.1: We do not hear anything about Kandaraka after this exchange.
comment_text.mn51:4.3: Yāva supaññatta is also at DN 18:22.3; it is a variation of the standard yāva subhāsita.
comment_text.mn51:4.4: The Buddha sometimes taught devotional meditations such as the six recollections for lay people, but passages such as this show there was no fundamental difference between lay and monastic meditations.
comment_text.mn51:5.10: “With self become divine” (brahmabhūtena attanā) deliberately echoes Upaniṣadic language. Pali is sometimes said to lack reference to the cosmic Brahman (in neuter), having only the personal Brahmā (in masculine). The grammatical case of brahma- in the compound here is undetermined, yet no scholar of Sanskrit would hesitate to interpret the common phrase brahmabhūtātmā in the sense “self become one with the cosmic divinity Brahman”. Surely the Pali draws from the same sense, using it to describe Nibbāna.
comment_text.mn51:6.14: Presumably Kandaraka left too. This sutta has an odd structure, as the bulk of the teaching occurs after the protagonists leave. This has the ring of a genuinely random encounter.
comment_text.mn51:8.1: For these practices, which were pursued by the Buddha before his awakening, see notes at MN 12:45.1.
comment_text.mn51:10.2: The same vivid description of ritual is found at MN 94:12.2 and AN 4.198:6.2. | The passage features many details close to the sacrifice as described in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, especially chapter 3, to which I refer below. Of course the attitude is the exact opposite.
comment_text.mn51:10.3: Santhāgāra is normally a hall to gather for business, a “town hall”. Here, however, the term draws on the idiom yajñasya saṁsthā, (“completion/establishment of the sacrifice”), which is so common the term “sacrifice” may be left out as implied (eg. 13.2.4.2). Thus it is “a building for completing the sacrifice” (commentary: yaññasāla). | The hall for sacrifice, referred to simply as śālā (3.1.1), is oriented to the east, for “the east is the quarter of the gods” (3.1.1.6). | Shaving hair and beard before the sacrifice is described in detail (3.1.2). | The anointing is with navanīta (“fresh butter”, 3.1.3.7 ff.). | The sacrificer wears clean linen (3.1.2.13), but sits on antelope hide (3.2.1.1), scratching himself with the horn (3.2.1.31; cf. Rig Veda 7.18.7). | The wife’s fertility cleanses and heals (3.5.3.13, 3.8.2). A king enters the “fire chamber” (agnyāgāra) with four wives (13.4.1.8).
comment_text.mn51:10.4: He lies down to sleep in the evening (3.2.2.22), with his wives, but refraining from sex (13.4.1.9). | The spreading of grass is a regular feature of Vedic ritual (eg. 3.6.3.14).
comment_text.mn51:10.5: After shaving, the sacrificer consumes milk (3.1.2.1) from all four teats or fewer (9.5.1.6), breaking his fast with milk cooked with rice or barley (3.2.2.10, 14). | Milk is drawn from specific teats (3.4.4.26, 9.5.1; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.8.1). | Milk is cooked from a white cow with white calf (5.3.2.1), or in another rite from a black cow with white calf (9.2.3.30).
comment_text.mn51:10.7: The slaughter of animal victims is described in detail (3.7.3). | The sacrificer ought not use the worldly term “slaughter” (Pali haññantu = Sanskrit jahi), rather “make them agree”, “persuade” (saṁjñapaya, 3.8.1.15) so they look forward to being sacrificed (3.7.3.4). | Trees are felled to make the stake (yūpa) to which the animals are tied, while grass (darbha) is strewn on the altar (3.6.4).

root_text.mn51:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā campāyaṁ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ.
root_text.mn51:1.3: Atha kho pesso ca hatthārohaputto kandarako ca paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā pesso hatthārohaputto bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn51:1.4: Kandarako pana paribbājako bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
root_text.mn51:1.5: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho kandarako paribbājako tuṇhībhūtaṁ tuṇhībhūtaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ anuviloketvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn51:2.2: Yāvañcidaṁ bhotā gotamena sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.
root_text.mn51:2.3: Yepi te, bho gotama, ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṁyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṭipādesuṁ—
root_text.mn51:2.4: seyyathāpi etarahi bhotā gotamena sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.
root_text.mn51:2.5: Yepi te, bho gotama, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṁyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṭipādessanti—
root_text.mn51:2.6: seyyathāpi etarahi bhotā gotamena sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito”ti.
root_text.mn51:3.2: Yepi te, kandaraka, ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṁyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṭipādesuṁ—
root_text.mn51:3.3: seyyathāpi etarahi mayā sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.
root_text.mn51:3.4: Yepi te, kandaraka, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto etaparamaṁyeva sammā bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṭipādessanti—
root_text.mn51:3.5: seyyathāpi etarahi mayā sammā bhikkhusaṅgho paṭipādito.
root_text.mn51:3.6: Santi hi, kandaraka, bhikkhū imasmiṁ bhikkhusaṅghe arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā.
root_text.mn51:3.7: Santi hi, kandaraka, bhikkhū imasmiṁ bhikkhusaṅghe sekkhā santatasīlā santatavuttino nipakā nipakavuttino;
root_text.mn51:3.10: Idha, kandaraka, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
root_text.mn51:3.11: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
root_text.mn51:3.12: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
root_text.mn51:3.13: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassan”ti.
root_text.mn51:4.1: Evaṁ vutte, pesso hatthārohaputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn51:4.3: Yāva supaññattā cime, bhante, bhagavatā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya.
root_text.mn51:4.4: Mayampi hi, bhante, gihī odātavasanā kālena kālaṁ imesu catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharāma.
root_text.mn51:4.5: Idha mayaṁ, bhante, kāye kāyānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
root_text.mn51:4.6: vedanāsu vedanānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
root_text.mn51:4.7: citte cittānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
root_text.mn51:4.8: dhammesu dhammānupassino viharāma ātāpino sampajānā satimanto, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.mn51:4.10: Yāvañcidaṁ, bhante, bhagavā evaṁ manussagahane evaṁ manussakasaṭe evaṁ manussasāṭheyye vattamāne sattānaṁ hitāhitaṁ jānāti.
root_text.mn51:4.14: Yāvatakena antarena campaṁ gatāgataṁ karissati sabbāni tāni sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni vaṅkeyyāni jimheyyāni pātukarissati.
root_text.mn51:4.15: Amhākaṁ pana, bhante, dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā aññathāva kāyena samudācaranti aññathāva vācāya aññathāva nesaṁ cittaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn51:4.17: Yāvañcidaṁ, bhante, bhagavā evaṁ manussagahane evaṁ manussakasaṭe evaṁ manussasāṭheyye vattamāne sattānaṁ hitāhitaṁ jānāti.
root_text.mn51:5.4: Cattārome, pessa, puggalā santo saṁvijjamānā lokasmiṁ.
root_text.mn51:5.6: Idha, pessa, ekacco puggalo attantapo hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
root_text.mn51:5.7: idha pana, pessa, ekacco puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
root_text.mn51:5.8: idha pana, pessa, ekacco puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
root_text.mn51:5.9: idha pana, pessa, ekacco puggalo nevattantapo hoti nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn51:5.10: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn51:5.11: Imesaṁ, pessa, catunnaṁ puggalānaṁ katamo te puggalo cittaṁ ārādhetī”ti?
root_text.mn51:5.12: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, ayaṁ me puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn51:5.13: Yopāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, ayampi me puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn51:5.14: Yopāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, ayampi me puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn51:5.15: Yo ca kho ayaṁ, bhante, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati—
root_text.mn51:6.1: “Kasmā pana te, pessa, ime tayo puggalā cittaṁ nārādhentī”ti?
root_text.mn51:6.2: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānaṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
root_text.mn51:6.3: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn51:6.4: Yopāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so paraṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
root_text.mn51:6.5: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn51:6.6: Yopāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
root_text.mn51:6.7: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn51:6.8: Yo ca kho ayaṁ, bhante, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati;
root_text.mn51:6.9: so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ neva ātāpeti na paritāpeti—
root_text.mn51:6.10: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn51:6.11: Handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bhante, gacchāma;
root_text.mn51:6.14: Atha kho pesso hatthārohaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn51:7.1: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkante pesse hatthārohaputte bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.mn51:7.4: Sace, bhikkhave, pesso hatthārohaputto muhuttaṁ nisīdeyya yāvassāhaṁ ime cattāro puggale vitthārena vibhajissāmi, mahatā atthena saṁyutto abhavissa.
root_text.mn51:7.5: Api ca, bhikkhave, ettāvatāpi pesso hatthārohaputto mahatā atthena saṁyutto”ti.
root_text.mn51:7.7: yaṁ bhagavā ime cattāro puggale vitthārena vibhajeyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
root_text.mn51:7.8: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn51:7.9: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
root_text.mn51:8.1: “Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo acelako hoti muttācāro hatthāpalekhano naehibhaddantiko natiṭṭhabhaddantiko; nābhihaṭaṁ na uddissakataṁ na nimantanaṁ sādiyati;
root_text.mn51:8.2: so na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti na eḷakamantaraṁ na daṇḍamantaraṁ na musalamantaraṁ na dvinnaṁ bhuñjamānānaṁ na gabbhiniyā na pāyamānāya na purisantaragatāya na saṅkittīsu na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī; na macchaṁ na maṁsaṁ na suraṁ na merayaṁ na thusodakaṁ pivati.
root_text.mn51:8.3: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko;
root_text.mn51:8.4: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;
root_text.mn51:8.5: ekāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti—iti evarūpaṁ aḍḍhamāsikaṁ pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
root_text.mn51:8.6: So sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti; vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
root_text.mn51:8.7: So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṁsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti;
root_text.mn51:8.13: iti evarūpaṁ anekavihitaṁ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
root_text.mn51:8.14: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn51:9.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
root_text.mn51:9.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo orabbhiko hoti sūkariko sākuṇiko māgaviko luddo macchaghātako coro coraghātako goghātako bandhanāgāriko, ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
root_text.mn51:9.3: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn51:10.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
root_text.mn51:10.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo rājā vā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto brāhmaṇo vā mahāsālo.
root_text.mn51:10.3: So puratthimena nagarassa navaṁ santhāgāraṁ kārāpetvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kharājinaṁ nivāsetvā sappitelena kāyaṁ abbhañjitvā magavisāṇena piṭṭhiṁ kaṇḍuvamāno navaṁ santhāgāraṁ pavisati saddhiṁ mahesiyā brāhmaṇena ca purohitena.
root_text.mn51:10.4: So tattha anantarahitāya bhūmiyā haritupalittāya seyyaṁ kappeti.
root_text.mn51:10.5: Ekissāya gāviyā sarūpavacchāya yaṁ ekasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena rājā yāpeti, yaṁ dutiyasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena mahesī yāpeti, yaṁ tatiyasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena brāhmaṇo purohito yāpeti, yaṁ catutthasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena aggiṁ juhati, avasesena vacchako yāpeti.
root_text.mn51:10.7: ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā assā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā rukkhā chijjantu yūpatthāya, ettakā dabbhā lūyantu barihisatthāyā’ti.
root_text.mn51:10.8: Yepissa te honti dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
root_text.mn51:10.9: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn51:11.1: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati?
root_text.mn51:12.1: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.mn51:12.2: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn51:12.3: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.mn51:13.1: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
root_text.mn51:13.2: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
root_text.mn51:13.3: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn51:13.5: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
root_text.mn51:13.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn51:13.7: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya, mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya, appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya, mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā, kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn51:14.1: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṁ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
root_text.mn51:14.2: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn51:14.3: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
root_text.mn51:14.4: Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.
root_text.mn51:14.5: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya—iti bhinnānaṁ vā sandhātā sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn51:14.6: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn51:14.7: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.mn51:15.1: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn51:15.2: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti, sapattabhārova ḍeti;
root_text.mn51:15.3: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn51:15.4: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn51:16.1: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn51:16.2: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn51:16.7: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn51:16.8: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn51:16.9: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn51:17.1: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
root_text.mn51:18.1: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
root_text.mn51:18.2: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn51:19.1: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn51:19.2: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti,
root_text.mn51:19.3: byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn51:19.4: thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn51:19.5: uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn51:19.6: vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn51:20.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
root_text.mn51:20.2: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
root_text.mn51:21.1: vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
root_text.mn51:22.1: pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
root_text.mn51:23.1: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn51:24.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn51:24.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn51:25.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn51:25.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn51:26.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn51:26.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn51:27.1: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn51:27.2: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn51:27.4: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn51:28.1: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn51:28.2: So attantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharatī”ti.
root_text.mn51:28.4: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn51:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn51:1.3: Then Pessa the elephant driver’s son and Kandaraka the wanderer went to see the Buddha. When they had approached, Pessa bowed and sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn51:1.4: But the wanderer Kandaraka exchanged greetings with the Buddha and stood to one side.
translation_text.mn51:1.5: He looked around the mendicant Saṅgha, who were so very silent, and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn51:2.2: How the mendicant Saṅgha has been led to practice properly by the worthy Gotama!
translation_text.mn51:2.3: The perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly at best do so
translation_text.mn51:2.4: like the worthy Gotama does in the present.”
translation_text.mn51:3.1: “That’s so true, Kandaraka! That’s so true!
translation_text.mn51:3.2: The perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly at best do so
translation_text.mn51:3.3: like I do in the present.
translation_text.mn51:3.6: For in this mendicant Saṅgha there are perfected mendicants, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment.
translation_text.mn51:3.7: And in this mendicant Saṅgha there are trainee mendicants who are consistently ethical, living consistently, alert, living alertly.
translation_text.mn51:3.8: They meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
translation_text.mn51:3.10: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn51:3.11: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn51:3.12: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn51:3.13: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.”
translation_text.mn51:4.1: When he had spoken, Pessa said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn51:4.3: How well described by the Buddha are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation! They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.
translation_text.mn51:4.4: For we white-clothed laypeople also from time to time meditate with our minds well established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
translation_text.mn51:4.5: We meditate observing an aspect of the body …
translation_text.mn51:4.8: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn51:4.10: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though humans continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.
translation_text.mn51:4.11: For human beings are shady, sir,
translation_text.mn51:4.13: For I can drive an elephant in training,
translation_text.mn51:4.14: and while going back and forth in Campā it’ll try all the tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints that it can.
translation_text.mn51:4.15: But my bondservants, servants, and workers behave one way by body, another by speech, and their minds another.
translation_text.mn51:4.17: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though humans continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.
translation_text.mn51:4.18: For human beings are shady, sir,
translation_text.mn51:5.1: “That’s so true, Pessa! That’s so true!
translation_text.mn51:5.4: Pessa, these four individuals are found in the world.
translation_text.mn51:5.6: One individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
translation_text.mn51:5.7: One individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
translation_text.mn51:5.8: One individual mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
translation_text.mn51:5.9: One individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
translation_text.mn51:5.10: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.
translation_text.mn51:5.11: Which one of these four individuals do you like the sound of?”
translation_text.mn51:5.12: “Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three individuals.
translation_text.mn51:5.16: I only like the sound of the last individual, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”
translation_text.mn51:6.1: “But why don’t you like the sound of those three individuals?”
translation_text.mn51:6.2: “Sir, the individual who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn51:6.3: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.
translation_text.mn51:6.4: The individual who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn51:6.5: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.
translation_text.mn51:6.6: The individual who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn51:6.7: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.
translation_text.mn51:6.8: The individual who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn51:6.10: That’s why I like the sound of that individual.
translation_text.mn51:6.11: Well, now, sir, I must go.
translation_text.mn51:6.12: I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.mn51:6.14: And then Pessa the elephant driver’s son approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn51:7.1: Then, not long after he had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.mn51:7.2: “Mendicants, Pessa the elephant driver’s son is astute.
translation_text.mn51:7.4: If he had sat here an hour so that I could have analyzed these four individuals in detail, he would have greatly benefited.
translation_text.mn51:7.5: Still, even with this much he has already greatly benefited.”
translation_text.mn51:7.6: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
translation_text.mn51:7.7: May the Buddha analyze these four individuals in detail. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn51:7.8: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn51:8.1: “And what individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? It’s when an individual goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared for them, or an invitation for a meal.
translation_text.mn51:8.2: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
translation_text.mn51:8.3: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
translation_text.mn51:8.4: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
translation_text.mn51:8.5: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
translation_text.mn51:8.6: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
translation_text.mn51:8.7: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
translation_text.mn51:8.8: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
translation_text.mn51:8.9: They constantly stand, turning down seats.
translation_text.mn51:8.10: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
translation_text.mn51:8.11: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
translation_text.mn51:8.12: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.
translation_text.mn51:8.13: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
translation_text.mn51:8.14: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
translation_text.mn51:9.1: And what individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
translation_text.mn51:9.2: It’s when an individual is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, or poultry, a hunter or trapper, a fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher, a jailer, or someone with some other kind of cruel livelihood.
translation_text.mn51:9.3: This is called an individual who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
translation_text.mn51:10.1: And what individual mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
translation_text.mn51:10.2: It’s when an individual is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
translation_text.mn51:10.3: He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the hall with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
translation_text.mn51:10.4: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
translation_text.mn51:10.5: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the leftovers.
translation_text.mn51:10.7: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
translation_text.mn51:10.8: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
translation_text.mn51:10.9: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
translation_text.mn51:11.1: And what individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, but lives without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?
translation_text.mn51:12.1: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.mn51:12.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn51:12.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn51:13.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
translation_text.mn51:13.2: They gain faith in the Realized One
translation_text.mn51:13.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn51:13.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn51:13.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn51:13.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn51:14.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn51:14.2: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
translation_text.mn51:14.3: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
translation_text.mn51:14.4: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
translation_text.mn51:14.5: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.mn51:14.6: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn51:14.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.mn51:14.8: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
translation_text.mn51:14.9: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
translation_text.mn51:14.10: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
translation_text.mn51:14.11: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
translation_text.mn51:14.12: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
translation_text.mn51:14.13: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
translation_text.mn51:14.22: They refrain from running errands and messages;
translation_text.mn51:14.26: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
translation_text.mn51:15.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn51:15.2: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
translation_text.mn51:15.3: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn51:15.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
translation_text.mn51:16.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn51:16.2: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn51:16.3: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn51:16.4: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn51:16.5: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn51:16.6: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn51:16.7: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn51:16.8: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn51:16.9: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
translation_text.mn51:17.1: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.mn51:18.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
translation_text.mn51:18.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn51:19.1: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn51:19.2: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.mn51:19.3: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence.
translation_text.mn51:19.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.mn51:19.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.mn51:19.6: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.mn51:20.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn51:20.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn51:21.1: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn51:22.1: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn51:23.1: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn51:24.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn51:24.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn51:25.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn51:25.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn51:26.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn51:26.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn51:27.1: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn51:27.2: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn51:27.3: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn51:27.4: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn51:28.1: This is called an individual who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
translation_text.mn51:28.2: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”
translation_text.mn51:28.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn51:28.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
